stem: The nurse is preparing for potential medication emergencies. Match each medication or substance with its corresponding reversal agent (antidote).

rationale.correct: Knowing antidotes is a fundamental safety skill. (r1) Protamine sulfate neutralizes Heparin. (r2) Vitamin K (slow) and PCC (fast) reverse Warfarin. (r3) Naloxone is the opioid antagonist for respiratory depression. (r4) Flumazenil reverses benzodiazepine sedation. (r5) Calcium gluconate is used for magnesium toxicity (especially in OB settings).
rationale.incorrect: Mismatching antidotes can be fatal (e.g., giving Vitamin K for Heparin will not stop the bleeding).
clinicalPearls: Flumazenil can trigger seizures in patients with chronic benzodiazepine use or in those who have co-ingested tricyclic antidepressants.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Connect Heparin with Protamine (Both start with letters in the middle of the alphabet?) and Warfarin with K (W-K sounds like 'weak'?). Or just memorize: Heparin/Protamine, Warfarin/K.

mnemonic.title: A-N-T-I
mnemonic.expansion: Antagonize the effect, Naloxone for Narcotics, Transition (slow reversals like Vit K), Immediately available.

reviewUnits.heading: Critical Rescue Pharmacology
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must know where antidotes are stored and how to administer them. High-alert medications (like Heparin and Insulin) require dual-signature and immediate access to reversal strategies.
